articles.headline: Under Missile Strikes, Ukrainians Haul Water, While Surgeons Work in the Dark
articles.snippet: “Every hour is getting harder.” Russia’s assault on Ukraine’s essential services has caused blackouts in hospitals and cut off power and water in cities.
articles.abstract: “Every hour is getting harder.” Russia’s assault on Ukraine’s essential services has caused blackouts in hospitals and cut off power and water in cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — In the crowded operating room, the surgeons had made the long incision down the middle of the child’s chest, cut the breastbone to spread the rib cage and reach the heart. Then the lights went out.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak

articles.headline: This Holiday Season, the Poor Buckle Under Inflation as the Rich Spend
articles.snippet: Even if policymakers achieve a gentle economic slowdown, it won’t be smooth for everyone.
articles.abstract: Even if policymakers achieve a gentle economic slowdown, it won’t be smooth for everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: November has been busier than expected at the Langham Hotel in Boston as luxury travelers book rooms in plush suites and hold meetings in gilded conference rooms. The $135-per-adult Thanksgiving brunch at its in-house restaurant sold out weeks ago.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Tony Luong

articles.headline: The Expanded Child Tax Credit Is Gone. The Battle Over It Remains.
articles.snippet: A pandemic-era program that sent monthly checks of up to $300 per child to most families drove down poverty rates. Amid new research about its merits, some Democrats are vowing to bring it back.
articles.abstract: A pandemic-era program that sent monthly checks of up to $300 per child to most families drove down poverty rates. Amid new research about its merits, some Democrats are vowing to bring it back.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the history of American hardship is written in some distant decade, two recent events may capture the whipsaw forces of the age.

articles.headline: ‘Gangnam Style’ Brought K-Pop to the World, but Haunted Its Creator
articles.snippet: In 2012, the song took over the internet, and it helped pave the way for the global success of Korean pop. But Psy, the artist behind it, spent years trying and failing to replicate the phenomenon.
articles.abstract: In 2012, the song took over the internet, and it helped pave the way for the global success of Korean pop. But Psy, the artist behind it, spent years trying and failing to replicate the phenomenon.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL — He may not look it, in a spiffy double-breasted suit and a coiffure secured with enough hair gel to reflect the ceiling lights, but the 45-year-old music executive confides a secret as he rubs his temples: He’s hung over.
articles.byline: By Jin Yu Young and Victoria Kim

articles.headline: China Is Finally Trying to Fix Its Housing Crisis
articles.snippet: After a year on the sidelines, Beijing this week took steps to get hundreds of billions of dollars into the hands of the country’s flailing real estate developers.
articles.abstract: After a year on the sidelines, Beijing this week took steps to get hundreds of billions of dollars into the hands of the country’s flailing real estate developers.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a year after one of China’s biggest real estate developers began to collapse, trouble has rippled through cities across the country. Dozens of other developers have also missed debt payments, the sale of new homes has plunged and construction cranes have come to a standstill at many sites.
